top_comment.text:
Could this process be sped up by educating the child before they figure 
these out themselves, or that'd do more harm than use, because their brain 
is not ready?﻿
top_comment.author: 1234kalmar

comments.text:
the individual attention, eye contact, social interaction, and shared time 
between an adult (particularly an attachment figure) and a child will 
always be beneficial. there is some interesting research on eye contact 
activating the limbic system (stimulating emotional intelligence and 
empathy). But no you cant force a 2 year old to understand theory of mind, 
but interacting and exposing children to varied and interesting stimuli 
will always be a good idea.
comments.author: Readyin10

comments.text:
Cognitive development can be sped up, but only to a certain extent. 
Development isn't solely cognitive development, but also physical and 
emotional development, and each that play a role in the overall development 
in a child. Without the same level of development throughout all stages of 
development, some concepts may not be fully understood until the levels are 
in a type of equilibrium with each other.
comments.author: Jordan Wilson

comments.text: +GTHeavy Y Thanks for the elaborate answer :) It's intereting :)
comments.author: 1234kalmar

comments.text:
The process may be sped up. Vygotsky's theory essentialy says that culture 
(and within that - a specific way to raise a child or specific environment) 
might speed up the stages. The problem is that there's a ton of variations 
and interpretations on how to speed it up and what the child actually needs.

There is no harm in trying to explain complex problems to a child, but you 
have to have in mind that they might just not get it. It's not about not 
trying or not wanting to learn, and even not about not understanding. They 
just understand things differently.

However, what might harm a child is unrealistic expectations. A parent is 
usually around when psychologists test their children (More example 
questions: what there is more of: roses or flowers/boys or children? Is a 
rope the same length when it is straight and when it is bent around a 
corner? ect.), and sometimes they freak out when their child "fails to 
answer questions as simple as this". Everything comes at its time.
comments.author: GTHeavy Y

top_comment.text:
But both of these views are really... wrong...
I come from a Linguistics background, and it's been pretty widely accepted 
that a modular nativist model such as Universal Grammar is the way to go. 
Nativism is a very hot subject with lots of different views, but so far 
it's the best we have. Far better than Piaget's or Vygotsky's one 
dimensional approaches. Chomsky's UG accounts particularly well for both 
the bizzare similarity and vast differences of child language development.﻿
top_comment.author: EmilyEmilyIris

comments.text:
In the end I reckon there will be no single framework for understanding the 
human mind that is even 70% "correct" or even quantifiably "wrong." The 
standard deviation might be less for a single model for a specific case, 
but that's it. I'd be happy to find a model that helps me understand just 
50% of my kid's behaviour.
comments.author: Daniël Cloete

comments.text:
I have a Bachelor's degree in Linguistics and find lots of issues with 
Chomskyan definitions of grammar. He laid a good framework, but its far 
from being 100% correct. A decent linguistics program should have taught 
you that.

Also, Vygotsky was one of the early champions of a social constructivist 
theory to language which is DEFINITELY not one dimensional.
comments.author: Byron McCuan

person #1 and therefore react less.

comments.text:

me a bit on the psychology of a child molestation victim and what to say?

comments.author: Chibi Redhead

comments.text:
+Darticus the Great
Also, if you know someone who is depressed you may want to check this out 
http://www.health.com/health/gallery/0,,20393228,00.html

It's a page on what to say and not to say to someone who is depressed. VERY 
HELPFUL. For example, NEVER, EVER say to someone who is depressed "you have 
to do this or that" or "try to feel better" or "you have to work, just 
try". Shit like that. We KNOW what we have to do, we just can't do it. A 
legless person will not walk, no matter what. A gravely depressed person 
will not think (effectively), until he or she is cured or treated. The best 
and often only thing you can do is show compassion and be there by their 
side without imposing anything, simply showing that you care.
comments.author: Gonçalo Teixeira

comments.text:
+Deliciousbutter
Please read my previous comments for understanding how depression works. It 
is not sadness.

Now, as to why people cut themselves, and I did too, is simple...sort of. 
You see, pleasure nerves are very closely linked with pain nerves, and 
seeing as depressed people feel like they "can't feel" things anymore, they 
just want to regain that part of themselves, to feel. All of us feel pain, 
even while depressed, even when pleasure is harder to achieve, so cutting 
ourselves is an "easy" way to feel "alive". It may also be an unconscious 
cry for help. If you know someone who does this, they need help. 
Immediately. And if you mock them you may be partially responsible for 
their possible death.

There's much more to it but I'll stop where my research stopped.
comments.author: Gonçalo Teixeira

comments.text:
+Darticus the Great What we do fully understand about depression however, 
is that it sucks shit
comments.author: degtyarev708

comments.text:
+Deliciousbutter
The reasons I outlined in my previous comment are why people who are 
depressed become sad. We are not sad to begin with. We are desensitised. 
Depressed people tend to, as was said in an earlier comment, LACK emotion, 
not, as many believe, have bad emotions. Those only come later.

I cannot stress this enough: depression is characterised by a loss of 
mental faculties that LEADS to a feeling of worthlessness and sadness, not 
the other way around. This cycle often last months or even years. No one is 
depressed for a few days, it is a long-lasting mental condition.
comments.author: Gonçalo Teixeira

comments.text:
+Darticus the Great
You're quite well informed on the subject, and as someone who has suffered 
from depression, consulted doctors, and conducted extensive research on the 
subject I'd like to just fill in some bits for the conversation. I am in my 
early twenties, by the way.

You are 100% right when you say that depression is a mental problem, not 
just emotional, and that associating depression with just sadness is 
completely missing the point. From my personal experience of 7 years of 
intermittent depression, and the research I have done, I can tell you how 
it works, at least how it worked for me:

1) At first you start to feel a bit more tired than usual. Everyone gets 
tired sometimes so you disregard this as anything serious and carry on.
2) You don't want to work as much anymore. Things that you were able to do 
previously in whatever line of work you're in become more tiring, even 
though there should be no reason for the change.
3) Because of this, you start to work less, simply because you just can't 
do it. I took refuge in masturbation and video games for a great part of my 
late teen years, and many other males do as well. If not that, then some 
other activity that deprives you of real human contact in favor of lonely 
pleasures.
4) You're getting worse now, and now view social outgoings as chores, as 
exhausting routines you drag yourself to. This is even more blatant if 
you're an introvert.
5) Now you may begin to suspect something's wrong. But you never tell 
anyone you're depressed, only that you're tired. Particularly if you're a 
male.
6) You're always tired, and you sleep for 10, 12, sometimes even 16 hours a 
day. You can't get any work done. The moment you start to work, or read, 
you become exhausted beyond hope, and go to sleep. The times you actually 
stick to it you end up procrastinating or, in extreme cases (like it 
happened to me), passing out from exhaustion.
7) You begin to feel worthless. Why? Several reasons: you can't work, so 
you can't contribute - you're worthless to society. All you do is sleep, 
because the dream world is better than this, and you don't have to work. 
You take refuge in lonely activities and disregard your friends - you 
become worthless to your loved ones, or so you firmly believe by this 
point. The world is moving at regular speed while you are operating on a 
numbed brain, so everything and everyone seems to be doing better than you. 
You feel worthless.

This cycle starts very subtly and lasts months, sometimes even years.
comments.author: Gonçalo Teixeira

comments.text: And don't anyone forget mirror neurons for the mention
comments.author: Arr Ziz

comments.text:
+Deliciousbutter
Sadness is a very poor definition of depression. The term "depression" has 
been greatly generalized by society to mean some great sadness, when it is 
actually much more than that. Sadness is an emotion, and depression is a 
one in a group of mental disorders. The mind is very complicated and 
certain parts of the brain differ greatly across individuals. As depression 
is a general term for many kinds of disorders and because of the above 
statements, depression cannot simply be generalized. It varies *GREATLY* 
across individuals to the point that a definition so simple as "sadness" 
just doesn't apply. Many depressed people feel sad, I'm not denying that. 
But other people who are depressed do not necessarily feel sad. It affects 
a broad range of emotions, including loss of interest/enthusiasm/feeling, 
suicidal thoughts/actions, stress, and of course sadness. It could affect 
any of those emotions but not necessarily all of them, depending on how the 
individual's mind functions/is structured.

I mean this whole argument on the large scale is really at a stalemate 
anyways, because the mind is so complex that we don't fully understand how 
depressions work. We're all kind of trying to grasp at straws and make 
assumptions that we're right when, collectively, we humans do not fully 
understand the disorder. It's hard to make reasonable conclusions about 
what's right when we don't fully understand it.
comments.author: Darticus the Great

comments.text:
No worries on the misunderstanding - I was rather terse and brash with my 
original statement, so there was little understanding to be had.

What I will say about the dictionary/Wikipedia thing is this: Wikipedia is 
quite good (when heavily referenced to reputable sources by lots of people) 
for gaining quick, condensed, and general knowledge on a topic, especially 
one you know almost nothing about.  I often used it when beginning research 
on a paper, although I never used it as an actual reference.  Dictionaries, 
on the other hand, are great sources for the common (and sometimes archaic) 
uses of words, since they (at least reputable ones like Merriam Webster) 
require a part of speech, a definite meaning, and "common" usage (although 
it may only be used in a specific field, like zoology, for instance). 
 Unfortunately, for something like "depression," the commonly understood 
definition (i.e., sadness) is entirely different than the clinical 
definition used in the psychiatric field.

I apologize for the extensive explanation on resources - I was a writing 
major in college. :)
comments.author: Kenny Stoneman

comments.text:
+elazer twist Anecdotal evidence isn't proof. And your friend must not be 
suffering from depression because the definition of depression is sadness 
and not lack of feeling.
comments.author: Deliciousbutter

comments.text:
+Kenny Stoneman
I mostly agree with you now, but I am still a bit confused. Why would 
practically any psych class disagree with his statement? It is not 
obviously blatantly misguided from what I can tell... it just generalizes a 
bit too much by giving definite reasons for (some) people cutting when it's 
all about the individual's reasons. I think that he was still right in 
saying that depression isn't all about sadness (although I guess it still 
varies by individual).

Although Wikipedia is quite a bad source, Dictionaries aren't very good 
sources either. They tend to reflect the ideas and possible 
misunderstandings of society, sometimes including "half-baked" definitions 
that don't quite capture the full meaning of the word. Take the word 
"depression" even, it's first (and thus the "best"/most relevant definition 
for most people) is "a state of feeling sad" when depression is clearly 
more than that. Another example of society's heavy influence on 
dictionaries is "twerk" and other pseudo-words added to some dictionaries.

Wikipedia is even worse, I know. Even though both sources are probably 
inspected by very many people to the point that most errors quite quickly, 
they are still not very good sources

I gotta admit though, you outmatched me in this argument :P Also, sorry for 
misunderstanding you :/
comments.author: Darticus the Great

Alright, sorry, this is actually from a few lessons ago, but does anyone

top_comment.author: Kathryn Jorgensen

comments.text: Okay, that makes sense. Thank you!
comments.author: Kathryn Jorgensen

comments.text:
You're comparing apples and oranges. Human language is far more complex 
than animal communication.

Children are not born with all the phonemes of the world in their head or 
we would all speak all the languages (or one super language, depending on 
how you look at it.) Some theorists believe we have the mechanisms to put 
it all together intrinsically inside of us, but we still need to hear the 
phonemes spoken aloud in order to know which are correct and how they are 
formed into words. As a baby goes from crying to trying to replicate these 
phonemes, it often comes across to us as just babbling, until they get the 
correct input and affirmation as to what sounds are correct sounds/words 
and what sounds are not correct sounds/words (correct in the sense of real, 
not proper).
comments.author: Byron McCuan

top_comment.text:

top_comment.text:
Why do kids like to see the same movie multiple times, to the point where 
an adult will be sick and tired of it? I remember watching The Lead Soldier 
movie a few times, and my parents tell me we actually broke the VHS from 
seeing it so much (twice a day, in fact). And I have seen kids play the 
same level of angry birds for hours straight. Is there any explanation for 
this behaviour?﻿
top_comment.author: NotaWalrus

comments.text: +Jovi Petra Out of all theories, this one made the most sense to me.
comments.author: edwardandeli

comments.text:
Lol true my nice watch dora the explorwr for 2 hours straight a day I am so 
tired of it lol
comments.author: ronel priela

comments.text:
hi, really good question. not a lot of specific research. but it has been 
found that children are soothed by repetitive actions and activities. they 
need the structure (watching the same dvd morning and afternoon) to make 
sense of their world and know what to expect in their daily lives. overly 
repetitive behaviour is generally thought to be a technique some children 
use to reduce anxiety.
comments.author: Readyin10

comments.text:
What else are kids supposed to do when they are bored? That is why I 
champion doing away with the drinking age. Stupid, medieval and barbaric, 
that's what I say. Can you imagine the stories they'd have by 21?
comments.author: Zach Mandelpoop

comments.text:
I still like watching and listening to things over and over. I'm not sure 
if that is a developmental tendency or personality quirk.
comments.author: angelcollina

comments.text:
This is just a suggestion, but could it be some kind of cognitive learning? 

A kid plays a game, it gives them pleasure. The kid now plays that game to 
be happy. 

So the kid connects that certain activity with pleasure hence doing it all 
over again even though he played that game before. But why are they not 
easily bored? i propose a suggestion that, as said in the video, the child 
had a schema of pleasure.

The kid knows playing the 1st stage of angry birds makes him happy, now 1st 
stage of angry birds equals happiness. The other may not be happiness, 
including different stages.

Of course, until the kid learns to accommodate new experiences related to 
what makes him happy. At this point angry birds will be boring for the 
child.

Please do decently argue with this comment, this topic interests me.

PS : The premise i had made makes me wonder, how happy a man could be he 
didn't have psychological accommodation. We can be happy with a single 
thing without the fear of boredom even though we will lose the will to 
create/do something new.
comments.author: Jovi Petra

comments.text:
Due to young children's development, children t young ages tend to have 
fixations on certain objects. This is due to the fact that attention at 
this time is very limited. The same is also true for mentally disabled 
people who, like children, can have extreme fascinations with a certain 
hobby or activity.
comments.author: Jordan Wilson

comments.text:
+Smile :D Disgusting?! That's being frank about being human dude. It's a 
shame you don't think beyond what I'm trying to imply. We seek that which 
gives us pleasure...and hold on to them once we consider them important. 
For babies the movies gives them pleasure, it's that simple. Same with your 
song, it's like women's boobs which drives men like crazy. Others think 
about food, relationships with people and the unseen as pleasurable. It's 
basic human fact.

We seek that which is pleasing, we avoid what can hurt or that which 
conflicts with our belief system, culture or norms. That's what you're 
doing right now... (boobs = taboo to you). Hahaha!
comments.author: IMNODOCTOR

comments.text:
+felipe970421  forget the boobs guy, that's disgusting. Thing about it like 
this, say you hear a song so good, it gives you goose bumps. You'll listen 
to it a thousand times. to someone who doesn't like the song, they'll 
wonder why you are obsessed with it. But to you, it sounds really good. 
eventually you will get bored though, like most children do. i guess since 
they have more of an imagination and more naive minds, that movie or game 
or whatever is the best thing in the world to them.
comments.author: Smile :D

comments.text:
Maybe it's because children rely more on current experiences and don't have 
fully developed memories. It's an intresting question though. Children seem 
to have so much fun by doing the same thing over and over while adults get 
bored easily..
comments.author: happyanne515

comments.text:
What's boobs is to us so is "FROZEN" is to them. You know it's a piece of 
skin but why is it that you like to watch them again and again? Same with 
kids.. they like to imagine stuff and don't understand what is real and 
what's not. :D
comments.author: IMNODOCTOR

comments.text:
well I used to do that. it felt good to watch episodes of mad jack the 
pirate over and over again. I still do it with lord of the rings.
with no psychological explanations, I can simply say that because doing 
things at that age is all about experiencing them. And when they feel 
really good you just want to feel it again. completing stuff doesn't really 
mean more than experiencing them, unless you are a robot.
comments.author: freastre

comments.text:
+felipe970421 Maybe its tied to memory? or maybe the lack of experience?

If a child tend to forget larger parts of the movie after every time they 
watch it they will feel like its something new everytime, or that they 
remember it was something they liked and they keep on doing it.

In the case of the lack of experience is that they dont know that there is 
something better, similar to the case of why kids dont want to eat food 
they never eaten before and go with the "i dont like it" and rather eat 
sweets or their favorite food all the time.

Maybe its a mixture, but i guess its kind of a "safety mechanism" that 
already tried out options give the best results and repeat until 
unobainable before they search for new options.
comments.author: dr4coknight

comments.text:
+angel60169 Oh my, I messed up the wording in that one really bad, sorry 
about that, not a native speaker.

What I meant to say is that every time he would play Angry Birds he would 
select the same level, play it for a while, then get bored. He's later pick 
up the game again and do the same thing.
 
There are countless other examples. My little cousin loves to be read 
Little Red Riding Hood, and every time he goes to bed he demands it. I know 
a kid who has watched Charlie and the Chocolate Factory over 15 times. And 
I once had to babysit a kid and had to memorize of bedtime story.

I am just curious about this behaviour.

top_comment.author: Max Schneider

comments.text:
The acquisition of this type of knowledge-large, abstract concepts- 
typically isn't fully acquired until adolescence . Children can understand 
parts of a concept such as imperialism, but fail to understand the depth of 
it until they reach the correct level of cognitive development.
comments.author: Jordan Wilson

comments.text:
a mix of brain maturation and continuous experimentation with and 
exploration of the world. Both piaget and vygotsky were very different to 
previous thinkers because they saw the child as very active in their search 
for knowledge, though vygotsky placed additional importance on the ways 
that parents and friends helped children in their discoveries.
comments.author: nuazak

captions.text:
Even though you can't see me, you know that
I am here talking to you. And I can probably

persuade you that this container of water
and this container of water have the same

amount of water, which they do, even though
they don't look like they do.

And you'll see I left my anglerfish behind
me. If someone were to move it without my

knowing, you'd rightly expect me to look for
it first where I originally left it.
...Nnnugh!!

You can figure out all these things because
you are far down the path of cognitive development.

Your parents will be proud. But there was
a time in your life, in all our lives, when
simple concepts like these were totally baffling.

Of course, lots of things influence how your
mind and its relationship with the world grows
over time.

Both our genetics and our environment begin
to affect our development long before we're

even born, and they continue to influence
our learning until the day we die.

And even though we're born with nearly the
same number of brain cells we'll ever have,

our complete set of brain hardware takes years
to solidify as our neural networks grow more
complex.

The study of our physical changes, cognitive,
social and emotional changes throughout our

whole lives - from prenatal to preteen to
post-retirement - is called developmental
psychology. It's how we grow into who we are.

And it begins with the growth of knowledge
itself: the process by which you mature into

the anglerfish-tracking water-beaker-estimating
peekaboo-master that you are today.
[Intro]

As we age, we tend to follow a sequence of
changes in behavior and appearance called

maturation. Everyone is affected differently
by their personal experience, of course, but
we all share inherent genetic growth tendencies.

We roll over before we sit, we sit before
stand, and we stand before we walk, and we

walk before we break dance. The same thing
applies to our cognitive development - how

we learn to think, know, remember and communicate.
And if you're gonna talk about cognitive development,

you gotta start with Jean Piaget, developmental
psychologist extraordinaire.

Piaget was from Switzerland where he was kind
of a wunderkind and got his PhD in zoology

in 1918, began dabbling in Freud psychoanalysis.
After graduation, he headed to France to work

on a method for testing children's aptitudes
and abilities. While administering these tests,

Piaget began to notice how younger kids kept
giving wrong answers to certain questions.

He became fascinated by the fact that children
of a certain age consistently made particular

mistakes that older kids and adults didn't.
Like the younger kids would have a really

hard time understanding the idea I just showed
you, that this container has the same amount

of water in it as in this container. Or that
this row of coins has the same number as this
row.

While others might have dismissed these as
childish mistakes, Piaget theorized that it

was because humans go through specific stages
of cognitive development and intellectual

progression. His main game was asking 'How
does knowledge grow?'

He proposed that as we grow and struggle to
make sense of our experiences, we create schemas,
or mental frameworks that help interpret information.

Schemas are like concepts, ranging from physical
things like birds and hats and eye patches
to abstract ideas like friendship and betrayal.

And we're constantly striving for cognitive
equilibrium, or harmony, between our thought

processes and our environments, which are
always giving us new things to think about
and adjust to.

Piaget proposed that we adapt to new experiences
through two processes that are closely related
- assimilation and accommodation.

When we assimilate new experiences, we interpret
them in terms of our existing schemas. So

if a toddler has never seen a deer but has
a schema for a horse, she may call the first

deer she sees a horsey. She wants to fit it
within her understanding.

But with more interactions in the world, our
minds expand to accommodate, or adjust to

new experiences. So soon enough, that kid
realizes that deer aren't just horses, and

she adjusts her schema. From there, she'll
be able to tell the difference between Bambi
and Black Beauty in no time.

But our knowledge base grows in ways that
are much more complex than just those two

steps, and Piaget knew that. He went on to
devise a four-stage theory of cognitive development

that described how we learn in different phases
of our lives.

He called stage one the sensorimotor stage,
which begins at birth and continues on to

about age two. This is the time when babies
experience the world through their senses

and actions. Touching and grabbing and looking
and hearing. And putting things in their mouth.

From what I can tell, mostly just putting
things in their mouth.

Younger babies may get scared around strangers,
seem to live only in the present, and have

to see something to know it exists. This makes
them very easy to trick, if you're into that

- I mean if you have any experience with babies,
just think about this: toss a blanket over

a six-month-old's pacifier and they think
it vanished.

They lack object permanence, the awareness
that things still exist when they're out of

sight. And yet, we develop so quickly that
just a month or two later that baby already

understands better that objects and people
don't disappear just because they're hidden.

Object permanence, in Piaget's view, was one
of the major achievements of the sensorimotor
stage.

The second of Piaget's phases of development
is the 'preoperational stage' and he believed

it began around age two, and carried on through
age six or seven. The thing about kids of

this age is that it's all about them. The
preoperational stage is characterized by 'egocentrism'

which drives most of what a child thinks and
says.

Kids have a hard time imagining another person's
point of view, so much so that when I was

a kid, if you asked me if I had a brother,
I'd say, 'sure, John', but if you asked me

if John had a brother I'd say, 'Nah, I don't
think so.'

Egocentrism of course never fully disappears,
even in adults who understand how the whole
sibling thing works.

The preoperational stage is also marked by
a child's ability to mentally represent objects

and events with words and images and pretend
plays in their imagination. They're big into

animism now, and believe their favorite bunny,
batman or stuffed anglerfish has feelings

and opinions and possibly the intent to kiss
or kill you when you're asleep - depending
on how they're feeling.
Still plenty of kinks to work out.

Piaget suggests that early in this stage,
kids don't yet understand the concept of conservation

- like how 500 milliliters is the same as
500 milliliters, no matter what container
it's in.

They can also struggle with the notion of
reversibility. It's hard for them to mentally

reverse the process by which a ball of clay
smashed flat can be rolled back into a ball.
It's a concept that takes some time to understand.

And these challenges both have to do with
'Centration' - a child's tendency to fixate

on just one aspect of a problem or object
- like the shape of the container or the clay.

But during the second half of stage two, things
begin to blossom. Kids start forming their

theory of mind or ability to understand other
people's feelings, thoughts and perceptions-

as well as their own- and also how to predict
behavior... like remember when my anglerfish

got moved when I wasn't looking? A child at
this stage will begin to realize that while

she knows that the fish is in a new place,
I don't know it was moved, so when I start

to look for it, she'll expect me to look where
it originally was and not where it was moved
to.

These new people skills have all kinds of
awesome applications from trying to convince

your parents to "PLEASE GIVE ME THAT EXTRA
COOKIE I SO DESPERATELY NEED!" to showing

empathy, which is better - and offering comfort
to others when they seem sad.

Piaget called the third stage of development
- beginning around age six or seven and lasting

until eleven or twelve - the 'Concrete Operational
Stage'. Kids are starting to think logically

about concrete events that they've actually
experienced. And unlike children in the earlier

phase, getting hung up on issues of centration,
kids in this stage experience 'decentration',

and become able to see beyond just one aspect
of an object or problem.

So now, problems with reversibility and conservation
just cease to be problems. And the last of

Piaget's four stages is the 'Formal Operational
Stage' which starts at about twelve and carries

us through the rest of our lives. By now,
our reasoning is expanding to include more

abstract thinking, problem solving and hypothetical
questions.

Now Piaget's four-stage model has been criticized
for over-simplifying things and for being

too rigid in how it classifies certain abilities
by age. Today, for example, researchers have

detected these phases at earlier ages than
Piaget ever did - sometimes way earlier - like

some types of object permanence have been
observed in three-month-olds.

Psychologists also see development as more
of a continuous process rather than a series

of stepping stones. But even Piaget understood
that his stages weren't as fixed as he made
them sound.

And he wasn't the only guy on the block talking
about development. For instance, his contemporary,

Belarussian psychologist Lev Vygotsky, had
some ideas of his own. While Piaget focused

on how a kid's mind grows by interacting with
his physical environment, Vygotsky emphasized

how early development occurs through parental
instruction and interaction with social environments.

He believed less in set stages and more in
the idea that care-giver adults provide a

sort of scaffolding, that helps children climb
to higher levels of thinking and learning.

Vgotsky put a lot of emphasis on language
as a way of assigning meaning to things, and

he also suggested that the ways kids develop
might actually vary across cultures.

In the end, there's room for lots of different
theories here, but perhaps Piaget's greatest

achievement was developing theoretical depth
in the concept that kids actually think very
differently than adults.

This fact has helped a lot of parents and
teachers, and his work spurred a new era of

research in the field. While Piaget wasn't
the only developmentalist, or even the first,

he's definitely one of the most influential,
and remains relevant to this day.

As the brain and mind develop in children,
so too do their social, emotional, and moral

behavior. How a child is raised and cared
for can have a profound impact on their personality

later in life, which is something we'll look
at next week.

This week, though, you learned how we use
schemas, assimilation, and accommodation to

make sense of the world around us, and about
Piaget's four-stage theory of cognitive development,

including sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete
operational, and formal operational periods,
and about Vgotsky's theory of scaffolding.

Thanks for watching, especially to all of
our Subbable subscribers - you are the reason

that we can do this, thank you. If you would
like to sponsor an episode of Crash Course,

or even be animated into an upcoming episode,
just go to subbable.com.

This episode was written by Kathleen Yale,
edited by Blake de Pastino, and our consultant

is Dr. Ranjit Bhagwat. Our director and editor
is Nicholas Jenkins, the script supervisor

is Michael Aranda who is also our sound designer,
and the graphics team is Thought Cafe.

title: The Growth of Knowledge: Crash Course Psychology #18
